name: Naturals to Rationals
description:
### Article Reference

For a detailed explanation of the underlying concepts, you can refer to [this article](https://mathcenter.oxford.emory.edu/site/math125/rationalEnumeration/#:~:text=Theorem%3A,the%20sets%20can%20be%20found). It provides an in-depth look at the topic and is highly recommended for further reading.

## Introduction

You've likely heard the phrase *some infinities are bigger than others*. While most just hear it once and then parrot it out without understanding it, its true meaning is a fascinating topic in mathematics, particularly when exploring proofs and set theory.

Today, we will explore a proof that the set of natural numbers, denoted `$\mathbb{N}$`, has the same cardinality (size) as the set of rational numbers, denoted `$\mathbb{Q}$`.

To demonstrate that two sets have the same cardinality, we need to establish a bijection between them. Therefore, our task is to enumerate `$\mathbb{Q}$`.

We use the following sequence to achieve this:

![sequence](https://imgur.com/xhObQTv.png)

Starting at `1`, for all `$n \in \mathbb{N}$`, there exists a corresponding fraction in `$\mathbb{Q}$`. This sequence will eventually cover **every rational number**.

However, for a bijection to exist, the mapping must be **injective**, meaning it cannot have **repeated elements**. Consequently, we skip any **reducible fractions** such as `(2, 2)` or `(6, 3)`. This gives us the sequence:

```python
1/1, 1/2, 2/1, 1/3, 3/1, 1/4, 2/3, 3/2, 4/1, 1/5, 5/1, ...
```

To be honest, this only proves that `$\mathbb{N}$` has the same cardinality as `$\mathbb{Q_+^*}$`. However, an experienced reader should be able to conclude the proof without much hassle.

## Task

Given a **positive integer** `n`, return the `n`th term of this sequence.

There's a very big optimisation requirement for this challenge, so you're expected to improve almost every aspect of your solution.
Do note that:

- An optimal solution should be able to complete the tests consistently, even if that takes most of the available time.

- All expected optimisations are algorithmic; thus, no major implementation details should be important.

```python
Random Tests: 115
Input Range: 1 <= n <= 1e12
```

### Examples

```python
1 -> (1, 1)
2 -> (1, 2)
3 -> (2, 1)
5 -> (3, 1)
7 -> (2, 3)
10 -> (1, 5)
```
